summary: This document is an email chain between legal counsel in the case of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, discussing procedural matters related to filing reply briefs and redactions. The correspondence details negotiations between the defense and prosecution regarding which portions of legal filings should be redacted or sealed to protect privacy interests, particularly of victims, third parties, and Assistant U.S. Attorneys (AUSAs).

persons.name: GM Jetter
persons.context: Sends the initial email stating intent to file an attached letter per the court's order and coordinates the filing of reply briefs and redactions.

events.title: Court Order on Filing Procedures
events.description: The court issues an order (Dkt. 232) regarding the filing of documents, prompting counsel to coordinate the public filing of reply briefs and letters with proposed redactions.

events.title: Court Adoption of Government Redactions
events.description: The court adopts the government's proposed redactions to certain exhibits (referenced in Dkt. 168) to protect privacy interests.

events.title: Submission of Joint Letter
events.description: The parties submit a joint letter to the court, which Judge Nathan later orders to be docketed or have redactions proposed by April 19, 2021.

keyFacts: The correspondence reveals ongoing negotiations between defense and prosecution over redacting names of Assistant U.S. Attorneys (AUSAs), accusers (victims), and third parties in legal filings to protect their privacy.

The defense indicates it redacted AUSA names 'as a courtesy' and takes no position on those redactions, while the government seeks to keep certain exhibits sealed to protect victim and third-party privacy.

Multiple reply briefs (1, 3, 5, 6, 10) are discussed, with disagreements centering on whether information designated as 'Confidential' by the government under a Protective Order should be publicly filed.
The document highlights the procedural tension between public access to court records and the protection of sensitive personal information in a high-profile criminal case.
